B00000AFDW|3.0|I have been a Kiss fan for YEARS. I supported them and defended them for years. Although a little confused over the departure of Ace and Peter in the early 80's (like most kids my age), I gave them a fair shake. When Kiss went public with Lick It Up, the first album to feature them without makeup, I thought they finally had the chance to write and record material as musicians rather than performers. And I was right, year after year, album after album they never failed to compose great tracks for an undying metal world. Then...all they hype about a full-blown reunion with Ace and Peter became a reality with the MTV Unplugged release and a reunion tour. So what was next? A new album with Ace and Peter of course. Man, us Kiss fans were drooling over the idea...the day had come. I bought Psycho Circus the week it was released. My reaction?...well..... <br /> <br />Let's be straight up and honest here. The \\"reunion\\" album SHOULD have BEEN MUCH better. Sure, Pcycho Circus has a few great tracks (the title track being the best...), but the majority of it should have been filed away. This album is the result of two egomaniacs assuming that the songs THEY have chosen for the album are the best way to go..and I can see why they feel that way...to a point. <br /> <br />Although Ace and Peter are songwriters in their own right, they haven't quite written any memorable tunes on their own (save for Ace's EXCELLENT solo record during the Kiss days....) Paul and Gene on the other hand have polished their craft to near perfection over the years. Ace and Peter bailed on them, and they kept on truckin'. But the problem here is the majority of the songs are luke warm. <br /> <br />Phycho Circus is THE best track on the album, and very Kiss, with Paul Stanley's trademark vocals at an alltime high. <br /> <br />The next track Within is another great one featuring Gene's raspy true blue rock and roll voice, complete with backward guitar bursts and a solid deep, dark beat. <br /> <br />Track three is Pledge...which is also a great number and fits just fine on the album...another example of those great pipes courtesy of Stanley. <br /> <br />Into the Void is an Ace Frehley composition that, with help from Stanley, is the second best track on the album. Interesting enough, it was almost \\"canned\\" due to Simmons' lack of interest in the song. But Stanley and Frehley both stood strong and thank God for that...cause as I mentinoned, this is a strong, superior track to MANY of the others. <br /> <br />Next follows We Are One...which is the first one that should have been left off the album. While not necessarily a BAD song, it doesn't belong on the album and should have been saved for Simmons' latest solo effort. <br /> <br />You Wanted the Best had potential...a LOT of potential, if it had a different drum pattern. This track showcases vocals from all four members which gives the track a LOT of character. <br /> <br />Raise Your Glasses is another that had potential. The chorus portion of the song has some great chord voicings and the melody of the actual chourus is fantastic....very classic Kiss...but....the verse portions show symptoms of The Elder...an automatic \\"scrap\\" into the trash can... <br /> <br />Iv'e Finally Found My Way is a song written by Mr. Stanley and a couple others for Peter Criss to sing. While a decent track for Rod Stewart's latest indulgence, it does NOT belong on ANY Kiss album.  <br /> <br />Dreamin' is another example of a great chorus with a horrible verse melody that causes one to lose interest immediately. <br /> <br />1'000 Years is the final offering on the album courtesy of Gene Simmons. This is a perfect close for the album and is very effective in doing so. This one truly belongs.  <br /> <br />Although it failed to rank as a classic, the album sounds excellent. The guitars are rich and carry the album much of the way, the drum sounds are wonderful, the bass is deep and rich and the vocals are right on top, like icing ona cake. But too much polish and \\"so-so\\" songs make Psycho Circus a \\"listened to it a few times, but that's about it\\" album. Mr. Fairbain could have been the other reason (God rest his soul...). Listen to Aerosmith's later material, Van Halen's Balance and you can see a pattern. This album might have been much better had another producer been utilized. But he was at the top of the game with all the hits he produced with Aerosmith, I can't blame Kiss for giving him the torch. <br /> <br />Now, we have a band that is living on the legacy they created more than 30 years ago; with a different line up and still using the makeup. I feel like many of the fans do. They should either pack it in, OR take off the makeup and just make another album... with the latter in mind, at least they would represent what they truly are... a great rock and roll band!
B000001GQU|4.0|DG has two version of the Verdi Requiem from Fricsay, both in mono, and I suppose they've chosen to release the 1953 one over the remake from 1960 because it is generally considered more gripping and better sung. Fricsay takes the opposite tack from Giulini--there is no veil of reverence drawn over the music. In general, tempos are on the fast side (the Tuba Mirum goes at breakneck speed), and the soloists avoid any trace of sanctimony. As a result, this performance holds one's attention by its dramatic thrust while being the least Italianate I've ever heard (the tenor goes virtually sobless throughout the Ingemisco. Bravo!)<br /><br />The sonics are a bit tubby, the bass drum is a mile away, but the vocal soloists are close-up and clear. They aren't of equal ability. Maria Stader has a bright, lyric voice, rather in the vein of Gundula Janowitz, and a very secure technique. Mezzo Marianne Rodet has a full, plummy sound and sings just as securely. The men are weaker: tenor Helmut Krebs bawls right into the microphone at times (he is lyrical and secure in the Ingemisco, however), and bass Kim Borg can sound too sepulchral. But they work well as a team, and the RIAS forces, both orchestra and chorus (supplemented by the St. Hedwig's church choir), sing with musical conviction.<br /><br />You won't mistake this recording for a religious experience--it's refreshingly secular from beginning to end--but Fricsay's approach is powerful enough to have stood the test of time.  (BTW I own both the older budget issue and this newly remastered one but cannot tell much difference in sound between them.)
B0009HLDFU|5.0|I haven't listened to the actual music yet (in fact, I don't usually listen to music), but the copyright protection alone makes this two-CD set worth owning. Kudos to the band for inventing this copyright protection and convincing RCA to use it on all future Foo Fighters albums.
B000003FPN|5.0|How did he do it? Fritz Reiner was mean-spirited and uncomuniative with his musicians. He didn't even bother to move to Chicago during the period in the Fifties when he conducted the CSO. Yet in retrospect he presided over a golden age of performance and recording. Almost without exception the CSO's records for RCA, most in excellent Living Stereo, have survived as first-rate and sometimes first-choice in everything Reiner conducted.<br /><br />This controlled, magisterial Dvorak 'New World' is no exception.  There's nothing Czech about it--it's an international, virtuosic interpretation given to us in wonderfully detailed, natural sonics. Really, there's no reason to own another CD of this work unless you are in pursuit of the peculiarly Czech flavor imparted by Vaclav Talich in Prague. Czech conductors make the Scherzo a more earthy furiant, and Czech woodwinds have a rustic tang. The CSO floats on a cushion of effortless technique and perfect ensemble. Reiner's reading is dramatic but warm, lyrical and incisive by turns.<br /><br />His pupil Leonard Bernstein made his own, more exuberant New World some years after this one but without a shade of Reiner's refinement and discipline. I can't claim to have any particular interest in this symphony, which I left behind some time in college, but I still appreciate the absolute quality of Reiner's performance.
0312305060|5.0|I experienced The Hours backwards. I saw the movie and fell in love with it. Then I read the book a couple years later. As much as I loved the movie, the book is far more powerful and subtle. In an amazing feat, the actors were quickly replaced in my head by the characters so beautifuly described in the book. Some books get a lot of hype because they deserve it. This is one.
B000000OMP|4.0|From what I have read in a couple of rock guides this album was finished in 1983 with Mick Moody and Mel Galley on guitars. It was later re-mixed for America, at which point Moody left and former Tygers Of Pan Tang/Thin Lizzy guitarist John Sykes joined the band. Sykes had recorded the excellent Thunder And Lighting with Thin Lizzy in 1983. I am not sure how much input he had on SIN but I remember he was the only guitarist to appear in the Slow N Easy video. Anyways, I have heard every Whitesnake album and this one is their best. The riffs are good, the solos are melodic, the choruses are catchy, and the rhythm section is tight. The production by the one and only Martin Birch is very clear and robust. I like every song with the exception of just a couple tracks so I won't bother going into each one. 0060839872|5.0|It took a long time to write a review for this book. I generally try to write them within a week of finishing. It gives me time to absorb what I read yet it remains fresh in my mind. For some reason, this took a full 2 months before I wrote this review. That doesn't mean I forgot what I read, far from it. This book is so full of valuable discussion that it would be impossible to forget much of what it talked about. After all, the content here is heavy enough to maintain a cult following 30 years after it was first published. <br /> <br />Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance is quite a good book. I don't know how else to start this review, other than to say exactly that. It's a classic that sat on my pile of books for years and years (and years - really, it was that long) before I picked it up. That's a shame, because this is something I should have been picking up again and again throughout those years. More than likely a timeless classic, Zen stays in touch with all levels of reader despite taking on a very mixed subject matter.  <br /> <br />A philosophical journey brushed with Buddhist undertones, this is a mysterious autobiographical adventure where Pirsig jumps head first into a slowly moving story which delves in and out of the mind of the narrator. Focusing on the issue of value, Pirsig attempts to ferret out the core of quality which drives dinner conversation across the face of the Earth. What is good? What is bad? How do we assess elements of this nature which fit into these good and bad boxes? <br /> <br />Truth and value, pillars of our social institutions, come under the scrutiny of Pirsig in the pages of this book. Challenging illusions we delude ourselves into believing, the text offers numerous questions and commentaries which lead the reader to question many things they may have previously taken for granted. <br /> <br />Blending Eastern and Western thought, Pirsig walks down a well-trodden but poorly paved road that many in the West try and fail to comprehend. That doesn't mean Pirsig understands it any better (or worse) than others who have ambled down this same path. It merely means he walks down it, and lends space to both schools of thought without wholly selling out and decrying one as superior. An impossible stance to take for almost all who try. <br /> <br />At times the book does bog down in slow meditative conversation. I don't think it detracts enough to make the book less than excellent. But it is something to consider when going into it. Those expecting Earth shattering revelations will need to step back and reassess what they expect from a book. Much of the text is meant to be consumed and ruminated upon. Reading 100 pages in a day is a sure way to misunderstand most of it. You would do yourself a favor by limiting the number of pages taken in any one day to less than 10. Here is a book to promote thinking. Take the time to do just that. <br /> <br />This book can (and should) appeal to any variety of reader. However, it will likely appeal more to those who actively want to better themselves and their lives, but not in the typical American manner of throwing a fist-full of cash at it. The idea is foreign to many in a land of cash-based happiness. Pirsig does not address this. I merely bring it up to preface who might enjoy reading this. I imagine the Conservative base will not take kindly to the book. Likewise, people beyond a certain age (is that Thirtysomething these days?) will likely be less concerned with a lot of the ideas here, believing they already have all the answers they need. I strongly assert that any person from any angle can get a lot out of this work. <br /> <br />This is a book I plan on reading again. I have cautiously ordered his sequel, Lila, because this book was so good. I can't expect it to be nearly as good. But it goes to show how much I enjoyed the first one. Needless to say, this is highly recommended reading.

B000002TQV|5.0|Yes, I love \\"The Bends.\\"  And the Rolling Stones.  Simultaneously.      I never really got into Radiohead during the \\"Pablo Honey\\" period. I love \\"Bones.\\"  Words don't do it justice - listen to it and you'll see what I mean.  In fact, when Thom Yorke declares on the title track that he \\"wants to be part of the human race,\\" it sounds as if he's the spokesman for every outsider and misfit the world has ever ignored.      Get this one, even if you're not really into Radiohead.  At the very least, you'll see how diverse and creative a band they are.  ~LBS

0765348780|3.0|Like many others, I started to read Gardens of the Moon at the insistence of friends, who described his writing and fantasy series as at least as good, if not better, than George R.R. Martin and his Song of Fire and Ice series. I think this is a flawed comparison. Erikson draws as much on his own imagination and traditional \\"high fantasy\\" or \\"epic fantasy\\" as he does from authors like Glen Cook or Martin. Erikson definitely shares Cook's focus on military matters, but unlike the Chronicles of the Black Company, which follows a band of mercenaries for hire, Erikson's sweep includes a whole assemble of Empresses, nobles, thieves, military men and women, assassins, mages, gods, and more...and he flavors it with bits of poetry, history, and politics of the fantasy world. This is where he splits with Cook or Martin. And might be his undoing as well. It's simply too much for one book, even a 657-page one at that, to handle, and too much for me. <br /> <br />Many of the problems lie within the giant cast of characters, their interactions, their subplots, and Erikson's narrative style. I couldn't help but wonder if Erikson had fallen into the (Robert Jordan) trap of thinking bigger is better: there are 92 or 93 characters listed in the Dramatis Personae at the beginning of the book. While I'm thankful that Erikson provided it, I think it's a bad sign. After a few hundred pages into the novel, the characters  started to seem like faceless actors in an extended play, stomping onto the stage, shedding a fake tear or mouthing a sweet soliloquy, then tiptoeing off of it, for a repeat performance in some distant age. Eventually I couldn't keep track of characters, even main characters such as Whiskey Jack and Paran, because of the lack of time spent on them. Simply, words and time were spread too thin on too many characters. Martin's writing avoids this by spending at least a chapter or a couple chapters told from the viewpoint of a character, so that you can become used to the thoughts and actions of that viewpoint character, which adds a kind of shading and coloring to the story. However, Erikson often jumps between a dozen characters within a chapter, sometimes spending no more than a few paragraphs on a few, giving some idea about their thoughts and actions, but the lack of focus and familiarity make it harder for the reader to sympathize, much less know what is going on, with the characters. Also, when I started to forget plot and character details, it started to hurt their characterization. Whiskey Jack, Paran, and others never really \\"grew\\" or came off as anything else as military types. I've known military men all my life, and static is one thing they are not. <br /> <br />I recommend this with some reservations. Readers of Glen Cook, Robert Jordan, and some other authors will find a gold mine in Erikson's work, with its focus on world building and military action. It is better written than either Cook's or Jordan's works. However, this emphasis on military action above all, with some flimsy political, romantic, and betrayal intrigues thrown in, will probably not captivate long-time Martin readers. Instead of a hearty stew, they may be looking at several servings of cabbage soup.
0385513755|2.0|Like Michael Crichton, Dan Brown knows a hook when he sees it. Then, using his minimal talent, serves it up in a very run-of-the-mill mystery thriller. But again, it's not the writing that counts here (poor), or the plot (poor), or the characters (poorer still), or the dialogue (could it get much more pedestrian?), it's the hook. The hook, of course, is the search for the Holy Grail. It's the Priory de Sion, an idea already easily exposed to be false in books of readily available scholarly repute. (For instance: \\"The Da Vinci Fraud\\" by Robert M. Price.) It's the possibility that Leonardo painted clues to his heretical beliefs in his paintings. Now, this might have a basis in truth. Unlike Brown, Leonardo was a talented artist, a sublime artist...he was also gifted in so many ways he seems almost superhuman. And it is true he had no love for the Catholic Church and the teachings of that church. But the church paid him for his work, and so he did it. But stuck with doing it, he used his commissions to make comments on what he actually believed. The Last Supper is the perfect example of this. Brown takes it to ludicrous lengths, but Leonardo did mean to say that \\"John\\" to the right of Jesus is Mary Magdalene. His portrait of her in close-up is tender, delicate, stunning, and patently feminine to any unbiased eye. If you want to really get to grips...not with basically unimportant ideas about French bloodlines (who cares if 2 thousand later a million French people are distantly related to Jesus and Mary Magdalene; does this mean they KNOW something?)...but with a thrilling book about the Magdalene, you really ought to read \\"The Secret Magdalene\\" by Ki Longfellow. First rate book, first rate hook.
B00005JMFQ|4.0|This is a movie that I loved for many reasons.  It's sad, funny, and heartwarming, and has a great soundtrack.  Because it has all these qualities, I find it frustrating that the Director/Writer made some poor choices that I think hurt the movie. <br /> <br />On the positive side, there is a wide range of love stories, great acting, and a fun Christmas theme.  My personal favorite is the aging rock star storyline, mostly because Bill Nihy is hilarious.  I also like the way there's inter-racial relationships in the movie, and that they're treated as nothing out of the ordinary. <br /> <br />     (Warning - the rest of my review contains some plot details)  <br /> <br />But some of the stories could have been so much better, which to me is a shame when this movie had the potential to be one of the best.  In the story with Colin Firth falling for his housekeeper, there was definitely chemistry there, but for him to sweep her off her feet and ask her to marry him so quickly (especially when they didn't speak the same language) was silly.  Another mistake (though not as significant) was having the housekeeper's father keep putting down her over weight sister, which was meant to add humor to one of the scenes.  This was intended as comic relief, but to me it just came across as mean-spirited and not funny. <br /> <br />I also thought the story with Liam Neeson and his son (who recently lost his mother in the story) could have been written better.  The movie shows very little mourning on the boy or dad's part, even though the mother just died recently.  It tries to make it seem charming and cute that the boy's real reason for feeling sad is because he's in love, instead of grieving from losing his mother.  The only time they seemed to express their loss was the day of the mom's funeral.   Even the Dad is checking out an attractive lady by the end of the movie, even though his wife just recently passed away.  If I could rewrite that story, I would have at least had the mom/wife pass away a year ago, instead of so recently.  This would have made their behavior more believable to me. <br /> <br />The Hugh Grant story was charming and cute, although I don't think they allowed enough character development.  To me they didn't show enough of the woman's personality for me to feel like I knew her and wanted to see them end up together.  I think it would have helped if they had another scene or two showing her being loving/kind to others (or with some other admirable quality), instead of using her humorous swearing habit or naivity to make her stand out.  In general I guess I would have liked to see a little more substance behind their attraction for each other. <br /> <br />There are a few other quirks I would have changed too, but overall I still like this movie and think there are some great parts (some sad, some uplifting).  I recommend seeing it, but without young kids because there's quite of bit of nudity in one recurring storyline, and several with adult themes.  I just wish a few of the plot flaws were corrected so I could love this movie and include it in my favorites.

Bush to a T.)<br /><br />\\"Folly, in one of its aspects, is the obstinate attachment to a disserviceable goal.\\"<br /><br />\\"The wars of the League of Cambrai over the next five years exhibit all the logical consistency of opera librettos.\\"<br /><br />\\"...it should not be supposed that honor and dignity are better served by persisting in a wrong measure once entered into than by rectifying an error as soon as it is discovered.\\"  (From Benjamin Franklin.)<br /><br />\\"In the search for meaning we must not forget that the gods, or God for that matter, are a concept of the human mind; they are the creatures of man, not vice versa.\\"<br /><br />As Tuchman points out, folly does not consist only in going ahead with pointless wars. B000BP86OG|5.0|When the Darkness recorded their debut album, \\"Permission to Land,\\" they were fresh off the British pub circuit and limited on money and time.  The album was recorded quickly and cheaply; they played stripped-down classic rock and roll.  The mixing on the album left something to be desired; the music itself was good but the overall recording quality was muddy at best.   <br /> <br />The same problems do not plague this record. <br /> <br />The album is painstakingly recorded.  An expanded recording budget suits the Darkness well.  They are a band known for their bombast, and it runs wild with heavily overdubbed vocals, exotic instruments (pan flute at the beginning of the album, sitar, strings and lush keyboards) and harmonized guitar solos.  As previous reviewers have noted, the Darkness draw a large part of their inspiration from Freddie Mercury and Queen.  Therefore, this album doesn't necessarily break any new ground.  However, this album blows most current music out of the water for one reason: the Darkness' music is fun.   <br /> <br />In a time when nu-metal are emotionless and \\"emo\\" bands lament anything and everything, the Darkness are a breath of fresh air.  This is not to say that there is anything wrong with the aforementioned bands, besides the fact that entirely too many exist.  The Darkness, meanwhile, are a band known for catsuits and rock 'n' roll excesses.  This album is a good distillation of the fun-loving tendencies of the band.   <br /> <br />Take, for example, \\"Knockers.\\"  The name itself is cheeky, and the lyrics follow suit.  For the entirety of the album, the Darkness stick to a tried-and-true formula.  There are the hard rockers (\\"One Way Ticket,\\" \\"Bald\\"), the power ballads (\\"It Seemed Like Such a Good Idea at the Time,\\" \\"Blind Man\\") and the light-hearted romps (\\"Hazel Eyes,\\" \\"Knockers,\\" \\"Girlfriend\\"). <br /> <br />In the end, this album rocks.  If you dislike operatic and sometimes excessive falsetto, look elsewhere.  Otherwise, this is rock album to own.
1400082773|5.0|In Barack Obama's \\"Dreams from My Father\\" I discovered a fascinating brain and an accepting mind that came to terms with his dual inheritance.      He provided us with an insight of the African-American experience, of the hopes and dreams of the people, of the realities they confronted and of their failures. In his inspiring appearance at the Democratic convention, Obama emerged as a rising star in the American political scene, a relatable figure with a strong personality. His speech was very moving. The fact that this book was written before Obama gained so much political popularity, seems to be the reason it is so authentic, unlike many of the autobiographies we read.     This book, is the lyrical, unsentimental, and compelling memoir, of the son of a black African father and a white American mother.  Obama searches for a workable meaning to his life as a black American. It begins in New York, where Barack Obama learns that his father--a figure he knows more as a myth than as a man--has been killed in a car accident. The sudden death of his father inspires an emotional odyssey-first to a small town in Kansas, from which he retraces the migration of his mother's family to Hawaii, and then to Kenya, where he meets the African side of his family, and confronts the bitter truth of his father's life.  There he reconciles his divided racial inheritance.     This is one of the most well written memoirs I have ever read. At some points it reads so much like a novel that I stopped to check the cover and make sure there was no \\"as told to\\" or other writing credit. The prose is lean and lyrical - while occasionally the   themes are repetitive, overall I loved the circular nature of his exploration of life, race and class. I appreciated the honesty and integrity of his thoughts on black culture and the struggle to define blackness and appreciate life in the US. I think he exposes a lot of the most painful truths about race in this country, while offering hope and reason - rather than condemnation - to both black and white.    I agree with other reviewers who have indicated that the book does feel unfinished. He did not spend much time discussing the people in his life that are and were very supportive (mother and grandparents) but I saw two reasons for this: First, the book is   unfinished in the sense that he is also \\"unfinished\\" and what it does cover is a sense of opening, discovery and closure around a complicated relationship with a parent that existed primarily in his own impressions.     Which brings me to reason #2: the unresolved relationship with his father fueled much of his early life choices. It feels only natural that these two stories be told in tandem. Now that he is a senator and much older through experience I would be curious to know how the telling of his life might change. As he indicates in the forward of the new edition - with so much distance between that experience and the life he's lived between Kenya and \\"now\\" there is much in his life that has to do with the impressions others like his mother and grandparents made. I suspect that it was rewritten to encompass more of his life, those other areas might balance the struggle to \\"find\\" his father and himself in those early years.     All that is to say: don't let his \\"preoccupation\\" with an absent father steer you away from this book. It in no way feels self indulgent or as an \\"open wound.\\" Instead, I found an inspirational journey and a thoughtful exploration that made for a quick read!     Barack Obama graduated from Harvard Law School in 1991, where he served as the first African-American president of the Harvard Law Review. He has worked as a community organizer, civil rights attorney, and law professor. Since 1997, he has represented parts of Chicago's South Side in the Illinois General Assembly, and he is currently the Democratic nominee to become the junior U.S. senator from Illinois. He lives in Chicago with his wife, Michelle, and daughters, Malia and Sasha.   =========================  Review by Stephen Rivers  For more visit us online

Harry Potter will always sell, but this movie does a good job keeping with the books without making the movie 3 1/2 hours long at the same time, not cutting out anything of great importance.

0061015725|4.0|This is a story of technology run amok.  In this case it is the narrator's wife's company that fails to control adverse outcomes.  This is also a tale of a two-career family since much of the couple's domestic life is portrayed. Jack's wife is the vice president of a nano manufacturing company, although nano is now a bad word to investors since so much had been promised in the past and not achieved.  Jack is a temporary house husband since he became a whistle blower in his own organization and has been deemed not a team player.  He had handled a bevy of programmers working in distributed processing,  and had found that all was not well when he undertook additional tasks in the security area.  He had trained as a population biologist and had sort of fallen into computer work.  Jack Forman has three children, Amanda, age nine months, Eric, age eight, and Nicole, age twelve.  He refuses to interview for jobs in Texas and New York since he believes his wife doesn't want to move.  He becomes a consultant at his wife's company when it is evident there is a problem, and since he knows the code he may be useful.      The facility is located in Nevada and the problem has to do with swarming.  Jack understands predator-prey relationships.  Angry predators do not lose focus.  Assembly lines move at the rate of one part per second.  This is called the build time problem.  Since nano-manufacturing has to be much more efficient, it is convergent assembly he is told.  The architecture is fractal.  Technologies are a form of knowledge.  They evolve, they mature.  The company is using bacteria to crank out their molecules.  It is genetic engineering, not nanotechnology.  An employee of the company claims it is a hybrid, a bit of both.  Jack is called upon to work at the company because there are runaway swarms.  No one else can deal with them.  Furthermore, the cloud has been self-sustaining for days.      The staff discovers gamma assemblers, used to break down carbon, have causedall the memory chips in their cars to turn to dust.  Obviously self-assembly is occurring in the desert from improperly vented bacteria and assembly pieces, or at least this is Jack's working hypothesis.  The swarms are reproducing.  Functionally, they are alive. How Jack unravels the problem and exterminates the swarms makes very exciting reading.  His personal travails on the domestic and romantic front engender reader identification.

B0007OCG4W|3.0|2004's \\"Closer\\" was directed by Mike Nichols, and it has a lot in common with his legendary 1971 film \\"Carnal Knowledge\\" (which stars Jack Nicholson).  Unfortunately, \\"Closer\\" isn't as profound as that earlier film.      Frankly, \\"Closer\\", although an interesting movie, is frustratingly hollow.  It has kind of a go-nowhere plot, with characters demonstrating baffling, erractic behavior for reasons that make basically no rational sense.  That said, each of the four main characters here are desperate, as well as emotional wrecks.  There are indeed a number of gripping scenes, with particular thanks to Clive Owen for his excellent portrayal of the sexually-obsessed and morally bankrupt dermatologist Larry.  Jude Law is also solid as the charming-on-the-surface but self-loathing obituary writer Dan.      The weak link in the chain, as far as the acting is concerned, is Natalie Portman.  She delivers an annoying, unconvincing, forgettable performance as a stripper supposedly named Alice Ayers.  The fact that she was nominated for an Academy Award doesn't speak highly of either the Academy or the current state of high profile movies.    The movie loses additional points for its prominent use of the absolutely horrible, pompous, pretentious, and predictable Damien Rice song \\"The Blower's Daughter\\".  This song is featured basically in its entirety at the very beginning of the movie, a terrible way to start things off.  As a worthless \\"bonus\\" feature, the DVD release features the music video for this excruciating and unimaginative song.    Overall, \\"Closer\\" is a good, watchable film, but it feels undercooked and ends up being disappointingly unsatisfying.

It's design is to make us think and make us realize that what happens to us will not improve due to the government or technology, but by the public demanding that the right thing is done, or else!   <br /> <br />Some of the reviews here belittle the conclusions and suggestions, and proclaim, \\"It can't happen here.\\"  Baloney. <br />I hope they are right. If this petri dish of a planet fails and collapses, you can't just rinse it off and start again.  That's it.  Over and out.   <br /> <br />So, should we continue in an indifferent fashion with heads in the sand, or learn how we can spread the word, and take public action to stop the insanity? <br /> <br />I don't have to believe everything written in the book to know how bad it's getting.  Take a 5 minute drive with your car window open in any major metroplex (gag).  Or try snorkeling in any US body of water.  How far can you see?  Then, try the same thing in China.  Yikes! <br /> <br />If your boss said, \\"Hey Bob.  We're moving your desk into the mens room at Yankee Stadium, ok?\\"  Bob wouldn't like that, right?  So, why do we want to live in a world the mimics that same mens room? <br /> <br />For the sake of your children and their grandchildren, it's now or never.  Some of the information in the book is also very helpful to understand what positive actions you can take to not be a part of the problem, but instead, a part of the solution. <br /> <br />

B00004RF9I|5.0|Paddy Chayefsky's 1976 film, NETWORK, won critical praise, audience approval, and several nods from the Academy, so that should indicate to anyone that this film is beyond brilliant. Chayefsky's searing indictment of broadcast television, and the news programs specifically, still rings true nearly 30 years later.  <br /> <br />Powerful performances by William Holden, Faye Dunaway, Peter Finch, and Robert Duvall keep the fierce satire going with nothing less than inspired performances. Sidney Lumet's direction is flawless. (Has this guy ever directed a bad film?) Punctuating the outlandish humor is the gut-wrenching poignancy of so many of the film's scenes. It's just too bad that none of the real television networks took note from this film; and Paddy Chayefsky might be rolling over in his grave, if he were to see the cable news networks of today. <br /> <br />Still, this is truly a groundbreaking film that must be on everyone's \\"must watch\\" list.  <br /> <br />P.S. -- The NETWORK trivia quiz at the end is a lot of fun.

B0006VIE4C|5.0|When Star Wars Episode III came out, I was advised to see one of the original movies before going to the new one. I wasn't that excited; I wasn't really a science fiction fan. And who really cares about a bunch of spaceships getting shot up and tall guys with capes and shiny black helmets getting decapitated by light-wand swords, anyway. <br />What I didn't realize was how much more the original Star Wars trilogy was than that. <br /> <br />\\"Whatever,\\" I thought. It was bound to be entertaining. So I willingly watched A New Hope. I finished it grinning from ear to ear. <br /> <br />I made up a new expression- don't judge a movie from its weapons (although lightsabers ARE really cool). Star Wars Episode IV was officially my favorite movie ever. <br /> <br />It was the characters that I liked so much. They're complex. Although Star Wars really is just another battle of good and evil, the twist is that nobody is just \\"nice\\" or \\"mean.\\" <br />I immediately loved those endearing sidekicks: R2D2, the stumpy little beeping robotic toddler, C3PO, the nervous gold protocol droid who won't shut up, and Chewbacca, that \\"big walking carpet.\\" <br />Han Solo is so arrogant and stubborn, but at the same time, lovable. Leia has the famous \\"just because you just rescued me doesn't mean I can't help you shoot the villains\\" attitude. And though Luke might not seem to have the immediate obvious personality of the other two, he has a likeable thing about him that makes you feel so horrible when bad things happen to him. <br /> <br />For those that don't know anything about Star Wars, I will explain that a Jedi is, first of all, a good guy, a member of a group that basically fights against the Empire (the bad guys) to save the universe. The Sith is a sort of dark Jedi. <br />The Force is a power that everything has, which can do just about anything that, to put it simply, a ghost could do. It can lift things, move things, squeeze things, all of that. The art to being a Jedi or Sith is touse the force to your advantage. <br />Droid is short for android, which is a robot. <br />A lightsaber (don't tell me you don't know what a lightsaber is) is basically a sword, except the blade is made of light. It can be turned off and on easily, which is useful because of its sharpness. It wouldn't be any good to go stabbing yourself with your lightsaber all the time. <br /> <br />The plot is fairly simple. <br />Young moisture farmer Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill), who lives with his Uncle Owen and Aunt Beru on the barren desert planet Tattooine, has big dreams. He has heard of the accomplishments of his late Jedi father, Anakin Skywalker, and he finds out that an Obi-Wan Kenobi (Sir Alec Guinness) taught him. Luke realizes that he has a neighbor named Ben Kenobi, and he is curious, so he decides to go see if the Kenobis have any relation to each other. <br />Luke finds out that Obi-Wan and Ben Kenobi are the same man. Obi-Wan promises to teach Luke the ways of a Jedi and the ways of the Force. After Luke's aunt and uncle's home is bombed by the Empire, Luke has no reason to stay- he has been sent on a mission: he must rescue the Princess Leia Organa (Carrie Fisher). <br />With the help of the droids R2D2 and C3PO, and also smuggler/pilot Han Solo (Harrison Ford) and his partner Chewbacca, a big, furry, howling Wookiee, and a lightsaber, Luke Skywalker rescues Princess Leia from the Death Star, a planet-sized ship belonging to the Empire, and faces many dangers, including Darth Vader. <br />That famous seven-foot-tall masked, caped individual is probably more robot than man, but it's hard to tell. His skill with both a lightsaber and the Force are almost impossible to beat. <br />Though Luke has many dilemmas along the way, the young hero is learning. He will be more than ready for training with Jedi Master Yoda in Episode V. <br /> <br />Anyway, I would DEFINITELY recommend this movie to anyone who wants to watch it. From my experience, people who watched Star Wars either loved it or hated it, so I am not guaranteeing anything, but one bit of advice would be this: if you are watching it for the violence, weapons or the special effects, watch Episodes I, II, and III, but I thought that these were lacking in personality and humor, as well (Anakin doesn't smile once in all of Episode III). Episodes IV, V, and VI are stuffed full of character and, though suspenseful at parts, have comic relief quite often. They may not have the best special effects by modern standards, but try to imagine that this is 1977. These were new concepts then. <br />These classics sucked me into the world of Star Wars (or should I say the universe) and I was glued to the screen the whole time. I was sad when the main characters were, and happy when they were. I think that George Lucas did a tremendous job with the original trilogy, but just lost momentum for the last three. <br />I still think Star Wars is one of the most amazing movies ever made, if not THE most amazing movie ever made. If you are considering watching it, I will say that it was nothing like how I expected, and I hope that you feel the same way. <br />Star Wars didn't gain the title of a classic for no reason. It is loved by the country, and if you look hard enough, you can find little bits and pieces from it in modern culture. <br />I hope you enjoy Star Wars Episode IV. Good luck and use the force!

B000001EAQ|5.0|Well, well, well.  I have finally arrived at POPmart, where the irony is served straight up, with a twist.  Perhaps U2's most maligned album, right up there with Rattle and Hum.  I shall initiate this review with a theory that I have read in other places, the U2 3-Album Cycle. I will place POP the the end of the final 3-album cycle.<br /><br />1)Boy, October, War---A friend of mine called this \\"Boy, Teen, Man.\\"  A somewhat linear beginning for the band, as they bring innocence and wonder on BOY, discovery and (religious) thunder on October, and greed and plunder on WAR.  Each album maturing from the last.  WAR is U2 finally going back to their punk influences after being \\"rootless\\" on their 1st 2.<br /><br />2)Unforgettable Fire, Joshua Tree, Rattle & Hum---Again, 3 albums that have a definite connection to another.  Another WAR would have pigeonholed the band's \\"sound\\", so they go back to another \\"beginning\\" for them; a more mature \\"European\\" album.  Joshua Tree sounds like the blend of WAR and UFire, making the sound more expansive while the songs more compact.  The logical conclusion of this 3 album cycle is a \\"live\\" album, and one where U2 goes back to roots they never quite owned, American music. (Note: UABRS, another U2 \\"live\\" album, came out after WAR).<br /><br />And Now the final 3 album cycle<br /><br />3)Achtung, Zooropa, POP<br /><br />Having cleared their creative decks twice, U2 followed the Rattle and Hum bombast underground, where they meant to \\"dream it all up again\\", another beginning, if you will.  But this time, their beginning was the end and everything in between, as U2 created arguably their finest ALBUM (i.e. beginning to end) Achtung Baby.  In many ways the manic energy level was akin to BOY; U2 were on fire.  They followed it up mid ZOO TV Tour with Zooropa, setting a very chill and fluid mood after the giddiness and grandiosity of Achtung baby.<br /><br />U2's POP was U2's first studio album in 4 years.  They had redefined music and concerts, cut a swath of flash and fury across America, and catured it all on ZOO TV: Live In Sydney, argualby their best concert video.  But now, they slowly emerged in early 1997 as ironic hipsters, a little jaded and a lot more mature.  They announced their new album/tour by playing a show at K-Mart.  They were tossing out names like Portishead, Prodigy, and Theivery Corp. as turn-ons. They announced that their tour would be one of a kind.  Judging off of ZOO TV, what else could the boys do to top that?  Had U2 gone techno? What's \\"space junk?\\"  What can we expect?<br /><br />The best.<br /><br />From the intro to \\"Discotheque\\" you can tell the boys have fun on their minds.  The edge fades in a great guitar intro, almost a reverse \\"Streets\\" riff, but thicker, with more funk and attitude.  \\"Do You Feel Loved\\" showcases Bono's falsetto at the end, while Edge both chimes and chars the guitar with fire and ice.  Perhaps the song that most detractors point to as U2 gone \\"techno\\" is \\"Mofo.\\"  This not quite surprisingly, is the best rock song on the album.  Thge Edge launches one bent note into the stratosphere over an unbelievable Adam-Larry groove.  Then at the midpoint, Bono pleas to hear his mothers' voice from beyond the grave as the music stops, then; just as quickly, the groove turns on again.  The first of two true ballads on this album, \\"Angels\\" is a great number about doubting your faith and God. The other ballad,\\" Staring at the Sun\\" is propelled by Edge's guitar sound and great lyrics from Bono.  Now the album takes a twist towards \\"Last Night On Earth\\", a manically ferocious rock song with the loud refrain \\"YOU GOT TO GIVE IT AWAY\\", a song addressed to a woman strung out and party-hungry, maybe having danced to \\"MOFO\\" earlier in the booze-soaked night.  This song had the same effect \\"The Fly\\" did in AB.  Now Bono seeks penance in the slower-tempoed rocker \\"Gone\\" as Bono declares \\"Goodbye/You can keep this suit of lights\\" an obvious reference to his rockstar status; more specifically the characters he played on the ZOO TV tour.  Another dense musical gem.  Next song \\"MIami\\" another song often brought up with disdain by those who felt U2 went \\"techno\\".  This song does sound like a B-side at times, but in the context of the album, it fits perfectly.  Bono compares Miami to a woman with some pretty funny lyrics \\"Miami! My mammy!\\" but it is also the sound of a lost soul looking for a place to go no matter how bad it is for him when he gets there.  Same goes for \\"The Playboy mansion\\"  a bit of funk blues guitar from Edge opens the doors to this song, as Bono states \\"We'll go driving through that pool/It's who you know that gets you through/the gates of the Playboy Mansion.\\" Still hasn't found what he's looking for....The album starts to crowd in on itself with the slow ballad \\"Velvet Dress.\\"  A wonderful bass line from Adam sets the tone for this song, a plea from Bono to his lover.  Then midpoint, Edge's guitar kicks in a very original way.  Next song \\"Please\\" Bono's update on Sunday Bloody Sunday\\" but with another great groove from ADam and Larry and a beautiful guitar riff by Edge.<br /><br />U2 has taken their fans to the edge of hell and the brink of heaven over the last 3 albums, and now POP collapses under its own weight and we are left with Bono pleading for Jesus' return in \\"Wake Up Dead Man\\".  As he sought to close his eyes at the end of AB with \\"Love is Blindness\\", as he sought redemption through Johnny Cash in \\"The Wanderer\\", Bono seeks to close this chapter of U2 by singing through what sounds like a broken nose, as Edge's melody is an insistent call above. \\"Jesus help me/I'm alone in this world/and a f***ed up world it is too.\\"  What a way to end an era for the world's greatest band.tus; more specifically the characters he played on the ZOO TV tour. This new version was written with Leonard Mlodinow and is titled A Briefer History of Time (Bantam Dell, 2005), and it was written to make the content of the original work more accessible to nonscientists and to bring it up-to-date with the latest scientific observations and findings. Although this book is somewhat \\"briefer\\" than the original, it actually expands on the great subjects of the original while leaving out some advanced technical matter (the mathematics of chaotic boundary conditions, for example!).\\"  (South TX Library System summary)

B00004X01U|4.0|Let's start off by saying that \\"Music\\" is a classic single. It belongs alongside such hits as \\"Holiday\\" and \\"Vogue\\" and contains that old Madonna magic. While there isn't another single like this on Music, the followup to 1998's brilliant 'Ray of Light', the album does hold the same spark of those good old days when Madonna wore fishnet and gyrated her way in the hearts of millions. It was 2000 when Music came out, and she is a slightly different Madonna. Where 'Ray of Light' was packed with introspection and slick, squiggly beats, 'Music'isn't quite so serious in either one. It's effortless, but at the same time maintains a charm not found on most modern pop records. \\"Music\\" is the best example of her \\"Lets just dance\\" approach, giving way to the slurping, dizzying \\"Impressive Instant\\". There are vocoders galore, and while they do seem a bit too much in some places, on tracks like the chilly, \\"Nobody's Perfect\\" and the almost menacing robo-slow \\"Paradise (Not for Me)\\", the digital effects work in a slinky, sneaky kind of way, allowing for those all important catchy hooks to set in. \\"Amazing\\" feels like a twin sister to \\"Beautiful Stranger\\", but the psychadelic guitar swirl is irresistably delicious. Even in her most stripped down, primitive ballads, \\"I Deserve It\\" is downright pretty, and while some rhyme schemes in the rootin tootin \\"Don't Tell Me\\" are cringe-worthy, it justifies that cowgirl hat she's been wearing these days. This song would make anyone want to dust off their  dancing boots. While all the songs have their own special something, it is \\"What it Feels Like for a Girl\\" that is the show stopper. It's glossy, it's sophisticated, it works so well, you can hardly believe Madonna has been crafting gems like these for two decades. For all those in doubt of her skills, 'Music' proves she's still got some spunk in her spurs. Did I make too many cowgirl references?

0553582453|5.0|I've decided in this review, to do all 3 books in the Tawny Man trilogy, (that being Fool's Errand, Golden Fool and Fool's Fate), as they are intricately connected (as you might expect) in the main characters, story line and writing quality.<br /><br />I enjoyed this series but with some minor reservations... let me explain<br /><br />The pros:<br /><br />The prose and story telling is of the highest quality with detailed description of persons, places and things. There is great character development throughout the entire trilogy; people you really like (or dislike) with a passion, and as with most fantasy novels, there is some magic and characters or creatures with special talents. The plot, although slow to develop, is interesting and intriguing; it grips you, making you eager to get back to these novels whenever you can. The writing itself has a nice, easy to read flow to it and follows in a logical sequence.<br /><br />The cons: Two niggling concerns: (and loss of  star)<br /><br />1.)The main character; ( Fitz) is best described as a reluctant hero with an overwhelming sense of guilt and continual self depreciation. In Fitz's opinion, everything that has ever gone wrong in this story can be traced back to the way he handled a situation in the past; and he is FOREVER agonizing about these thoughts (what he might have done different... etc.) Needless to say, three novels of this, and this character trait starts to wear a little thin.<br /><br />2.)Lack of action; I realize a great novel does not have to have \\"action\\", however having said that, I've always liked my fantasy novels to have a fair amount of \\"action\\" with some battles or combat (large scale or small). That is not to say this series has no action, because it does, but somehow I wanted more. The few skirmishes seemed so far apart, and I must admit this was somewhat disappointing.<br /><br />Although it may appear that my \\"concerns\\" mentioned above appear huge, such is not the case. This is a deep, rich fantasy series of epic proportions; well written and detailed, but just misses the mark of true greatness because of the shortcomings mentioned above. 4  stars.tailed, but just misses the mark of true greatness because of the shortcomings mentioned above. 4  stars.

And Johnny Depp gives a crazy/creepy aspect to Willy Wonka, which is exactly what I would have wanted, although with the caveat I mention below. So why didn't I like this film? <br /> <br />It's hard for me to say exactly.  Part of it is that the script seemed to drag in places.  Part of it was that I didn't care about the characters one way or the other; Charlie himself comes off so saccharine sweet, but in a way that didn't fit with the creepy hyper-cheerfulness of the rest of the flick, that I WANTED something untoward to happen to him.  Willy Wonka, while appropriately creepy, also came off more as a petulent, bitchy little brat, rather than as a mad genius / eternal kid.  And the little oopah-loompa songs, while a tip of the hat to the original movie, were juvenile. These are some of the things that bothered me.  Any one or two would have been OK, but the combo of all these and more doomed the film.  Clearly, this film is not for me. <br /> <br />The DVD itself is fine; clear picture, clear sound.  I must admit I was so disapointed by the film I didn't bother to watch the extras, if there are any.   <br /> <br />Like I said, I really wanted to like this movie, but for me it was missing that intangible something that makes Johnny Depp a great actor, and Tim Butron a genius film maker.

THE SONGS ARE A LOT TIGHTER ON THIS ALBUM; <br />   On previous albums, Some of their songs tended      <br />   to be a bit excessive in a way where there were too     <br />   much fat around the meat of their compositions (for     <br />   example, That long pause in \\"Whole Lotta Love\\"      <br />   and a even longer pause in the song \\"How Many More  <br />   Times\\"). I don't find that to be the case with any of  <br />   the tracks on their fourth album.  There are no long pauses  <br />   in any of the songs. Some may frown at the fact that I called their previous albums almost one dimensional. But I'm only being real and besides, you can't listen to their three previous albums and this album and tell me that the sequencing and the songs are not at their tightest and most focused on album 4. <br /> <br />I'm sorry if this was a bit long but when it comes Zeppelin's music, I have nothing but a \\"Whole Lotta Love\\".

0451457994|4.0|In the background Clarke introduces us to an advanced civilization that helped Earth's \\"dumb\\" apes evolve millions of years ago into modern humans by teaching them how to kill prey.  I'm fascinated by these mysterious characters lurking in the background.  They, like us, evolved from ocean slime, then into intelligent, self-aware carbon-based beings like us, then into machines, then finally into states of organized energy.  Then the reader is suddenly translated into modern times.  Humans, developing powerful artificial intelligent life, are at the cusp of taking the next evolutionary leap.  This, post-Darwinian evolution, is what 2001 is REALLY about--all of the conflict between humans and their AI life forms is just a side topic.  Unfortunately for me, this side topic makes the bulk of the book, which is definitely enjoyable on its own to be sure, and makes sense of the movie.    On the other hand, a book I recently read and strongly recommend, Beyond Future Shock by Alaniz, picks up where Clarke coldly left off.  Like 2001, it is a strong science fiction book.  Starting in WWI, tracking the lives, romances, struggles and triumphs of several infant Germans who will live through WWII, the Cold War, and into the age of youth cocktails when these \\"kids\\" are in their late 90s, Alaniz tracks the science behind the coming transhuman age with masterful, subtle \\"Clarkian\\" writing.  He also tracks the potential perils, and the problem of Luddism and religion versus science.  As you sink deep into Alaniz's powerful imagery, you will find yourself thinking about mankind's various potential fates in the coming few decades: some horribly dystopian some reasonably utopian. Singularity (read the new book by Kurzweil) will soon be upon on us.        For me, Alaniz has finished with genius what Clarke only touched upon in 2001.  I am fully sastisfied at last.    Paul

B00005JOHI|4.0|This is a beautiful version of the classic Jane Austin novel Pride and Prejudice. the actors and actresses are beautiful and the English countryside glows golden at sun rise and sun set. There are three aspects of the film that I will point out tht make it wonderful entertainment. <br /> <br />First, Elizabeth Bennett is one of the great characters in English literature. Here she is played as more impulsive than Jennifer Ehle plays the part in the great BBC version. For example, beautiful Kiera Knightley plays Elizabeth as young, playful, and inclined to romance, as evidenced by her reactions to Mr. Darnley at the country house dance at the beginning of the film. Jennifer Ehle pays Elizabeth Bennett as more reserved, more mature, and more sphnix-like. The strength of Elizabeth Bennett is that she is witty, intelligent, considerate, and willing to change her mind. It is this last quality, the willingness to changer her mind, on which much of the film revolves. Elizabeth's first impression of Mr. Darnley was that whereas he was rich and handsome, he was also arrogant and prideful an maybe even a little cruel. Eventually, through a series of mishaps and interactions, she begins to see him differently, seeing his strenghts and compassion and convictions and most of all, his love for her despite the tensions and misunderstandings they undergo.  <br /> <br />The scene where Darnley proposes to Elizabeth despite his low regard for her wild family and her poverty was wonderfully played in this film, with Kiera Knightley firing back at him that his poorly worded proposal of marriage was the height of insult to her and her family.Yet these two weather this upsetting event and go on to love each other greatly as they further discover each other's best qualities. Isn't this what love should really be about? Shouldn't we move from erotic first impressions to deeper appreciation and understanding of each other? <br /> <br />Second, Darnley is well played here. Colin Firth does such an exceptional job in the BBC version that it was hard for me to warm up to another Mr. Darnley, but this actor gives us a version of Darnley that is more mysterious and less aristocratic than the Firth version.  <br /> <br />Third, Jane Austin creates a charming world full of odd, delighful, endearing, and yet realistic characters. Jane Bennett is the height of beauty and sweetness, no wonder Mr. Bingley falls madly in love. Mr. Bingley is as silly as he is rich, however he is sincere and is a perfect match for Jane. Mr. Bingley's sister is wonderfully played and I loved the line she speaks at the country dance where she wonders when the guests will stop dancing and chase pigs. Lydia Bennett is such an empty headed young women, not realizing how her elopement could ruin the reputations of her sisters. Mr. Collins is such a fool, basing his self worth on the whims of his wealthy benefactor, Lady de Bourge. Judi Dench plays a great angry scheming Lady de Bourge. Mr. Bennett says in the book: \\"God placed us here on earth to laugh at our neighbor's folly and for our neighbor in turn to laugh at ours.\\" This line wonderfully represents Austin's philosophy which she brings to all her characters. <br /> <br />The acting is super and truly romantic, the English countryside is beautifuland moody, and the novel actually can be revealed in a short two hours, which I could not believe until I saw it.
B00005JO1P|4.0|Film biographies are always a bit tricky, in my opinion.  I always find myself wondering which parts are \\"true\\" and which parts are rearranged, condensed, combined, etc.  For example, in WALK THE LINE, there's a terrifically dramatic scene near the end when Johnny Cash proposes to June Carter.  The circumstances of the proposal are almost TOO perfect, from a storytelling / dramatic standpoint.  Did it really happen that way, or did the filmmakers take liberties because the truth would have been less cinematically interesting?  At least, when I watch fiction, I know it's all made up.  And when I watch \\"non-fiction\\", I know liberties will be taken...I just don't know where.    That aside, WALK THE LINE is a pretty satisfying film bio.  First of all, Joaquin Phoenix is terrific.  He doesn't really look like Cash...I always thought Cash was a big man...Phoenix is not.  But we forget these surface dissimilarities almost right away, because Phoenix embodies the character in more important ways.  He creates a full-blooded character.  And the fact that he sang the songs himself is pretty amazing.  Again, his voice isn't a dead-on copy (he can't quite as low as Cash), but there are enough times when a particular phrase comes out EXACTLY like we remember that the viewer is completely satisfied.  It was great to hear some older Cash songs that I had forgotten I knew.  Reese Witherspoon, as June Carter, gives her best dramatic performance yet.  She has one great scene when she is shopping in a small general store in some town they are touring through.  First, she meets some admiring fans and her manner in being perfectly lovely to them while still cutting their conversation short is terrific, and moments later, she is confronted by a clerk who heartily DISAPPROVES of June's recent divorce...and Reese's face is wonderful to watch.  We see her shame and a smidge (just a smidge) of anger...and her response (well written, but REALLY well delivered) is great.  This is a time beforeeveryone went around being sarcastic / ironic, and her reply is genuine and non-ironic and painful and totally appropriate.  There are times in the film when Reese's generic \\"perkiness\\" comes through a bit more than I would like...but overall, she's quite solid.  Phoenix should certainly get an Oscar nomination...Witherspoon is slightly less deserving, in my opinion, but I wouldn't put up a fight if she did get nominated.    One thing I really like is that the film plays out a lot of its drama right on stage.  The concert scenes are fabulously believable.  There's great singing and playing of great music, there's totally believable banter (I don't mean the banter is believable...it's totally \\"staged\\" for the audiences, but it feels exactly like what would have been delivered to audiences of the `50s & early `60s) and there's a LOT of subtext being played out.  Whether it's the looks Johnny gives to June as she waits off stage, or their chemistry when they sing together...you almost get all you need to know about their relationship by how the shows go.  When Johnny reaches rock bottom with drug use...we see it on stage.  When he's totally enamored of June, we see it on stage.  I love that the film makes this choice with its storytelling.    I also want to mention a great supporting turn by Robert Patrick (X-FILES, TERMINATOR 2) who plays Cash's father.  I don't think his part has Oscar written on it...it's not that showy.  But Cash's father has a HUGE influence on Johnny, and Patrick plays him strongly enough that we can palpably feel how Johnny is affected by him.  It's a critical role, and Patrick nails it.  After TERMINATOR 2, his roles on film haven't always been the best.  I hope this gets him some juicier material...Agent Doggett will always have a soft spot in my heart.    The movie isn't perfect.  I felt the Folsom Prison concert was just a bit of a dramatic letdown.  Yes, this is a famous album and famous moment in Cash's career, but the film tries to make an awful lot of it, and then they don't actually show us much of the show.  Also, the inevitable closing titles, when we are told in a few superimposed words about the rest of Johnny and June's lives are quite brief and uninformative.  Those two went on to rather amazing careers for another 30+ years.  The care and devotion they were shown in the film is quickly tossed aside in a few glib summary statements.  I think everyone in the audience would have happily sat and read a bit more...especially with some great Cash music in the background.  But these quibbles aside, it's a very entertaining movie and I would give it about 4.25 stars.

0393317552|3.0|On a recent trip to Central America; I got a chance to visit the ruins from the Aztec and the Mayan civilizations. Visiting this site one is quickly reminded of the utter destruction and sins committed by the western nations. The bestial rage of the conquering rabble can be seen in each of the acts designed to eternalize the conquest. The Aztec caste has long since vanished as a dominant power; their stone blocks enigmatically; impervious to the ravages of time. The white troops sacked the already defeated city; attacking the monuments with un-brindled fury. They unified the greed for the gold that covered the walls; in perfect representations of the sun god; with sadistic pleasure of exchanging the joyful and life-giving symbols of a grieving people for the bereaved idols of the joyful people. The temples were razed to their foundations or their walls were made to serve the ascent of the churches of the new religion.  At that time I was quite curious over the reasons for the disparities in the civilizations.  Why? The west had an advantage and achieved glory; leaving the proud cultures of America was sidelined.  <br /> <br />The answer to the question lies in this text. The answer, almost too clear and believable, is the luck of the draw of natural resources. The Eurasian continental landmass was the winner of the biological draw in two crucial ways.  <br />1. Most domesticable crops and animals  <br />2. Largest contiguous size of similar climate  <br />Having the larger number of domesticable species of plants and animals the Eurasians were able to over time develop their agriculture; employing the animals to undertake manual labor. Another advantage the Eurasian enjoyed were the expanse of the continent in the horizontal (east-west) direction; in comparison the Americas being aligned in the vertical (north-south) plain.  This ensured similar climates for a stretched region on the (East-West) axis. The development of agriculture gave rise to concentrated population; since habitants did not have to travel for long distances in search of food. The creation of cities; economy; trade politics; philosophy and technology evolved with the concentration of people in a small area.  <br /> <br />Diamond places plenty of evidence in supporting this claim. As in the text he describes the vestiges of technology enabled the Maori invaders from New Zealand sequester the Maoriori of Chatman Island. Interestingly both had the same ancestors separated from one other for a century.  Within the century the Maori tribe who had better climate; domesticated animals were able to harvest; create technology; develop methods of warfare. On the other hand the Maoriori tribe with severe climate and landscape; having no domesticated animals retained their hunter gatherer society. These limitations enabled their conquest. Further he discusses the Austronesian expansion into the Pacific, the Chinese expansion into Southeast Asia, and the Bantu expansion into sub-Saharan Africa, engulfing the pygmy and Koisan peoples. In each case the story involves a group of people who from a later point of view seem aggressive, conquering large areas of land and subjugating the previous inhabitants, if any. In each case, Diamond tries to show us that the same factors were at work: a superior set of crops and land-use techniques, leading to population growth and territorial expansion.  <br /> <br />Towards the end of the book, Diamond at last addresses an obvious question. His arguments for expecting Eurasian dominance over Africa, America, and Australasia leave us asking why Europe and not China, India, or the Middle East, has ended up dominating the world. Here his reasoning becomes less convincing. He suggests that China was too integrated, that its geographical connectedness made it too easily unified under stultifying dictatorships, whereas Europe had just the right amount of geographical fragmentation (Britain, Spain, and Italy are all walled off by mountains or seas) to keep power divided among competing regions of roughly equal strength, while allowing ideas to flow freely among them.  <br /> <br />This seems like a stretch. Taiwan, Japan and Korea are geographically separated from China, but shared with China an oriental reluctance to engage with the rest of the world. Also, these finer geographical features only become important after the development of organized states, at which point one would expect cultural factors to play some role as well. As we zoom in on specific areas in recent times, we have to abandon Diamond's large-scale scientific explanations, which discard cultural factors by averaging them out over large areas or long times.  He also fails to explain how the culture and civilization which surpassed Europe's in terms of technological advancement; architecture and art till 13th century; began to be surpassed with the one from Europe. <br />

Others seem upset that Mayer doesn't sound as good a SRV, who said that he was trying to beat or immitate him? A note to all you blues fans, if you really love blues then you would like more people to hear it and enjoy it too, right? Well, John Mayer and Johnny Lang and Kenny Wayne Shepherd are all helping bridge the gap between Rock/Pop/ and blues, and because they can fit the radio \\"mold\\" they can get more air time. Frankly if you are a hardcore blues fan, why are you listening to John? He is an established POP SINGER, and has blues influences. <br /> <br />That said, if you are a Mayer fan and haven't heard his live stuff, this will be a pretty wicked tranformation for you. If you haven't heard On Any Given Thursday yet, I suggest you buy that first (it has a lot more blues influence but is still poppy enough that it shouldn't turn anyone off- it is by far one of my favorite cd's). If you like his live cd \\"Thursday\\" better than his studio stuff, I would say you have a better chance of enjoying this cd. This cd has a raw sound compared to the rest of his material. If you thought that \\"Thursday\\" was a step in the wrong direction, I would advise you to save your money. There are great songs and some of them are very poppy, but overall, if you don't like \\"Thursday\\" you are likely to be someone that prefers a studio touch-up quality, and will probably not see the beauty of a live recording. Fans of blues, the stuff is tight, grooves pretty hard, but leans on R&B as well. The riffs are hotter than ever, the vocals are even edgier than his past live recordings, and yes their are many hints of SRV and maybe even more hints of Hendrix in his voice. <br /> <br />1. Who did you think I was - 5/5 Heavy, groovin song. Cool Lyrics  \\"Am I the one who plays the quiet songs?\\" This song explains the rest of the album. This is the music he loves yet this stuff doesn't fit the radio \\"mold,\\" so now he has produced a record on his own in order to make the music he loves. <br />2. Good love is one the way - 5/5 Great upbeat pop song with a great riff and good lyrics <br />3. Wait untill tommorrow - 4/5 Good song that has Hendrix-esqe style and has one particullar guitar/drum line with a break that reminded me of Dave Matthews style (1:10). <br />4. Gravity - 5/5 a quiet song that may get studio production and end up on the radio. May be my favorite off the cd. Sounds a lot like the stuff off \\"Thurs.\\" <br />5. Vultures - 5/5 One of the best white-boy R&B songs ever recorded. This song is old school, and it's hot! You NEED to hear this song! <br />6. Out of my mind - 3/5 Sweet solos, but John's voice wasn't made for this stuff. I gave it 3/5 because of the solos. <br />7. Another kind of green - 5/5 a nice song with a more \\"heavier Things\\" feel, but a little more technical. <br />8. I got a woman - 3/5 different sounding happy blues,r&b mix <br />9. something's missing - 5/5 I love this song. Remember, a 5 guy band reduced to 3, they pull this off very well. <br />10. Daughters - Ok, when I bought \\"heavier things\\" this wazs the only song that I didn't really love. Somehow this is the song they chose to kill on the radio. 3/5 caus i don't like it. 4/5 otherwise <br />11. try - 4/5 probably the hottest guitar work on the album. <br /> <br />

His stories have been made into episodes and was a major influence on Rod Sterling with stories such as \\"nightmare at 20,000 feet\\" and \\"little girl lost\\". His novels \\"Hell House\\" and \\"A Stir of Echoes\\" have been made into memorable movies.<br /><br />\\"I Am Legend\\" seems to me to be his best out of all his works. The book deals with the familar examples of what a vampire is but with an atomic age twist. The story is not centered on vampires but on the loneliness of one man and the effects of isolation from contact with other humans has turn his mental and emotional instincts off.<br /><br />Inside the story the character remembers what it is like to be a human again and we see what has turn him into the hermit we first meet thru flashbacks. But the most important part of the book is the twisted ending that Matheson is famous for.<br /><br />Less then two hundred pages but worth the money. You will never look at vampire novels the same way again.
020530902X|5.0|I was first required to buy Elements of Style as a college student. As is usually the case, I grumbled about buying what I considered yet another unnecessary book taking what little money I had .<br /><br />It turns out this was one of the few books I didn't immediately try to sell once I completed my course. Years after I graduated, I still find myself using it as a refresher as I do a lot of writing. Although it's not on the curriculum, I encourage my students to buy this book. The authors explain how to write in simple prose that everyone can understand. It's a little book compared to the big English volumes they have to carry around but I tell them it's the best money they'll spend in their college career and beyond.
B000BM6AVA|4.0|Now that we've heard it all you gotta wonder precisely what the whole point of the whole 'Mezmerize/Hypnotize' scheme.  It seems obvious, paying twice for a double album that actually coulda fit on a single cd anyway.  But if you got them right when they came out you probably only paid like 9 bucks for each of 'em, so the monetary difference ain't much of a concern.  Still I think the consumer came out a little behind, not because we paid too much but because we got more than we needed.  Simply put, when SOAD needed to come up with 20+ songs in a single session they came up with a few more clunkers than usual. (A problem typical of most double albums and pseudo double albums)  So, finally meandering to my point, 'Hypnotize' has 3 lousy tracks.  'U-Fig' is mostly just bland and uninspired, other than the chorus which is truly grating. (Though it's worth noting that I'm in the minority on this issue, as most people seem to enjoy that piece of crap.  In fact I seem to have received psychic comeuppance for my denouncing of the track as I just poured soda all over myself.  Back in a sec) Sadly, 'U-Fig' is quickly overthrown as the most irritating SOAD song as we arrive at 'Vicinity of Obscenity' and 'She's Like Heroin'.  Here SOAD's goofiness gets the best of them and they churn out to hideous novelty songs for those who can't distinguish between what's catchy and quirky and what's simply annoying and ridiculous.<br /><br />Still, the other 9 tracks are good, often great.  They retain the greater sense of melody they found with 'Mezmerize' and incorporate plenty of harmonies, which I feel really augment their sound.  Many hate Daron's singing and while he is annoying at times I think he's mostly acceptable and, again, works very well while harmonizing.  The instrumentation is strong and energetic and though they aren't really a Nu-metal band the instruments still largely just provide a base for the vocals.  There are a few neat riffs, but this ain't a thrash album or anything like that.  'Attack' is what you need from an opener, very energetic and driving though it still has SOAD's trademark sudden starts and stops. 'Dreaming' is perhaps the strongest track, with a great epic, harmonious chorus and strong dynamics.  'Tentative' is the next best thing, huge and emotional and apocalyptic.  'Holy Mountains' is the most ambitious, multi-faceted thing here.  Not every instance of it works, but it's very good overall.  They get a bit more emotional at the end, with the simple power-ballad 'Lonely Day' and the closer 'Soldier Side'.  This last one is perhaps a bit melodramatic at times, but they pull it off anyway and it's a fine capper to the whole project.<br /><br />Still, it shoulda been only 1 album.  Lop off those 3 track I mentioned here and combine it with 'Mezmerize' minus 'Old School Hollywood', 'This Cocaine....' and maybe one more relatively mediocre track of your choice and you've got the best SOAD album of their career.  But 'twas not to be, and it's not like anyone is making me listen to those tracks, so I suppose it's no huge loss.<br /><br />Lastly, the way the packaging of these albums is supposed to combine is lame, but whaddya expect.nything like that.  'Attack' is what you need from an opener, very energetic and driving though it still has SOAD's trademark sudden starts and stops. 'Dreaming' is perhaps the strongest track, with a great epic, harmonious chorus and strong dynamics.  'Tentative' is the next best thing, huge and emotional and apocalyptic.  'Holy Mountains' is the most ambitious, multi-faceted thing here.  Not every instance of it works, but it's very good overall.  They get a bit more emotional at the end, with the simple power-ballad 'Lonely Day' and the closer 'Soldier Side'.  This last one is perhaps a bit melodramatic at times, but they pull it off anyway and it's a fine capper to the whole project. <br /> <br />Still, it shoulda been only 1 album.
